subject: Re: [junit] Re: Recommended readings on more advanced (JUnit) testing
msgSnippet: Sorry. Can t think of such a project off-hand. Lasse -- Lasse Koskela * Author of Test Driven (Manning Publications, 2007) * * Reaktor Innovations *
messageBody:
Sorry. Can't think of such a project off-hand.

Lasse

--
Lasse Koskela
* Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
* Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *

On Fri, Feb 20, 2009 at 1:16 PM, majkic@... <majkic@...> wrote:
> Thank you very much for the hint. Do you have any concrete link? I
> think that wiring Struts2&Spring services for testing is the most
> difficult.
>
> Any ideas?
>
> Regards,
> Marko
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Lasse Koskela <lasse.koskela@...> wrote:
>>
>> Hi,
>>
>> On Wed, Feb 18, 2009 at 4:05 PM, majkic@... <majkic@...> wrote:
>> > Hi guys,
>> > we're working on a big project with several frameworks:
>> > Hibernate 3.3, Spring 2.5, Struts2.1, JUnit 4, Selenium. We're using
>> > Maven2, Hudson for CI etc.
>> >
>> > Is there any article/blog/book you could recommend for non-HelloWorld
>> > , i.e. more complex - with aforementioned technologies JUnit/Selenium
>> > examples/know-how?
>> >
>> > Thanks.
>>
>> It's somewhat inconvenient to publish complex examples as part of
>> articles or books, which is why my first suggestion would be to look
>> for open source projects that make use of your chosen testing tools,
>> check out their code base into your IDE, and browse those real world
>> examples in an environment suitable for the "non-helloworld" level of
>> complexity.
>>
>> Of course, you'll be missing on the narrative text that makes books,
>> articles and blog posts so convenient for getting started with a new
>> technology but I take it that you're not exactly new to JUnit and
>> Selenium since you're asking for complex examples.
>>
>> Lasse
>>
>> --
>> Lasse Koskela
>> * Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
>> * Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *
